title: Creating TechDocs from Source Code
description: Learn how to create TechDocs directly from your source code using mkdocstrings.
content:
You can create documentation by extracting information directly from the source code itself.

Instead of manually writing API documentation separately from your code, tools like *mkdocstrings* extract this information directly from your codebase and generate formatted documentation automatically.

sections.content: Key benefits Reduced duplication : You write explanations once (in your code) rather than maintaining separate documentation. Better synchronization : Documentation stays up-to-date with code changes

title: Template Visibity on the Templates Tab
description: Discover how to leverage the displayFilter attribute in Alchemy to define conditional visibility for templates based on metadata and entity context. This guide covers filter types, structure, operations, and common use cases.
content: The `displayFilter` attribute is a specialized metadata property exclusive to `Template` entities in Alchemy. It provides a query language to control template visibility based on entity context and determines which templates appear under the **Templates** tab.

sections.heading: Basic structure of displayFilter
sections.content: Basic structure of  The   attribute uses a declarative structure with three main logical operators that can be combined to create complex filtering conditions.  This structure provides flexibility to

sections.heading: Key concepts
sections.content: Key concepts Logical Operators: : All conditions must evaluate to true (AND logic) : At least one condition must evaluate to true (OR logic) : None of the conditions can evaluate to true (NOT ANY logi

sections.heading: Supported operations
sections.content: Supported operations These operations can be combined with the logical operators ( ,  ,  ) to create sophisticated filtering conditions that precisely target the entities where your template should be

sections.heading: inArray
sections.content: Checks if a specified field exists within an array item, with the ability to access nested fields.

sections.heading: notInArray
sections.content: Opposite of inArray. Returns true when no array items match the provided condition.

sections.heading: equals
sections.content: Performs exact string or value matching. Returns true only when the field value is identical to the input.

sections.heading: not
sections.content: The inverse of equals. Returns true when the field value is different from the input.

sections.heading: exists
sections.content: This function checks if a field exists and has a non-empty, non-null value. It is useful for confirming the presence of optional fields.

sections.heading: stringIncludes
sections.content: Checks if a string field contains the specified substring. Case-sensitive.

sections.heading: stringDoesNotInclude
sections.content: Checks if a string field does NOT contain the specified substring.

sections.heading: arrayContains
sections.content: Checks if an array field contains the exact specified value as one of its items.

sections.heading: arrayDoesNotContain
sections.content: Checks if an array field does NOT contain the specified value.

sections.heading: arrayContainsNone
sections.content: Checks if an array field contains NONE of the values from a provided array.

sections.heading: arrayContainsAny
sections.content: Checks if an array field contains AT LEAST ONE of the values from a provided array.

sections.heading: Common use cases
sections.content: Common use cases The display filter's flexible query language enables you to create precise visibility rules for your templates. Some common scenarios demonstrate how to use the filter conditions effe

sections.heading: TechDocs missing
sections.content: TechDocs missing It shows the template only for components that don't have TechDocs configured. Making documentation templates more visible where needed helps teams identify and fix documentation gaps

sections.heading: Environment specific
sections.content: Environment specific This targets only production components. This is useful for templates that add production-specific configurations like SLOs, alerting, or compliance checks. For the above example,

sections.heading: System and component integration
sections.content: System and component integration This shows templates for systems or components that belong to a system. It is perfect for templates that help manage system-level concerns or cross-component integrati

sections.heading: Domain-based templates
sections.content: Domain-based templates This filter targets domains related to financial services. It's useful for domain-specific operations like compliance reporting, specific audit tooling, or financial integration

sections.heading: Component specific
sections.content: Component specific This filter shows the template only for service-type components that aren't tagged as legacy. You can use this to provide templates for active services, like adding monitoring, CI/C

sections.heading: Can I use async operations in filters?
sections.content: Can I use async operations in filters? No, filters must be synchronous. Use actions for async operations.

sections.heading: How do I share data between filters?
sections.content: How do I share data between filters? Use template variables or chain filters together. Avoid global state.

sections.heading: Can filters modify the original input?
sections.content: Can filters modify the original input? No, filters should be pure functions that return new values.

sections.heading: Is there a limit to filter complexity?
sections.content: Is there a limit to filter complexity? While there's no hard limit, keep filters simple for maintainability and performance.
